Award.AwardTitle: Student Paper Competition and Student Volunteers for Virtual Participation at the 2010 IEEE MTT-S International Microwave Symposium. To be Held in Anaheim, CA on May 23-28, 2010.

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this activity is to provide partial travel support for ten students from U.S. universities to attend the 2010 IEEE MTT-S International Microwave Symposium (IMS). The IMS is the annual meeting of the Microwave Theory and Techniques Society (MTT-S) of the Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers, Inc. (IEEE). The IMS is also the major international symposium in the microwave field and a focus of research results in wireless telecommunications. The 2010 IMS will be held in Anaheim, CA, USA on May 23-28, 2010.

Intellectual Merit: The main impact is primarily educational, as the travel support allows students' participation in IMS 2010. This participation is an important part of the education process. It provides students with the opportunity to be exposed to new areas of research and to interact with more experienced researchers.

Broader Impact: Student participation at the IMS not only promotes education but also fosters the next generation of microwave engineers.

Institution.Name: Institute of Electrical & Electronics Engineers, Inc.
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: INSTITUTE OF ELECTRICAL AND ELECTRONICS ENGINEERS, INCORPORATED, THE

Performance_Institution.Name: Institute of Electrical & Electronics Engineers, Inc.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Report of distribution of travel reimbursements to the student paper contest (SPC) finalists for the International Microwave Symposium (IMS) 2010 held in Anaheim, California, USA

 

Report submitted by the PI: Prof Satish K Sharma, San Diego State University, Co-chair, Student Paper Contest, IMS 2010

Fund distribution decision was made by the SPC Chairs (Prof. Sharma and Dr. Deal) based on the travel reimbursement applications submitted by the SPC finalist students. The SPC finalist decision was made after peer review process as per the student paper contest rules posted on the symposium website. This travel support was limited to the students from the US Universities only.  Up to a Maximum of US$1250.00 for out of California students and up to $500.00 for the students from California was approved based on the travel reimbursement claim made by the students.

Fund Distribution was managed by the IEEE personnel (Avishag Klatzin). Students submitted filled travel claim forms with the necessary original receipts.  Total ten (10) students applied for the travel reimbursements and were approved for their travel claims which accounted to total of $7920.08 out of the approved funding of $10,000.00. The total unspent fund was $2079.92 which has been notified/returned to the NSF.


Last Modified: 08/21/2011
Modified by: Satish K Sharma
